Pregnancy, physiological changes

Pregnancy, physiological changes Purpose: supply metabolic demands of foetus, prepare for delivery.

Airway (the five Ts):

T ongue - increase in size

T ight larynx due to physiological oedema/ pre-eclampsia

T ime - ↓ FRC and ↑metabolism cause rapid desaturation

T oo much swelling of nasal mucosa to pass N-P airway

B reasts get in the way of laryngoscope handle. (Alleviated by head-up tilt, polio handle.)

Respiratory:

- ↑V T by 50% ∴ ↑alveolar ventilation, P a CO2 falls by 1kPa, P a O2 increases by 1kPa. Improves gradient for placental CO2 clearance.

- Diaphragmatic splinting

- ↓ FRC by 20%. Supine at term, FRC ↓ by 50%.

Cardiovascular:

- Na + and H2O retention ∴ ↑circulating volume (peak at 32weeks), ↑ cardiac output . Blood volume at term = 100mls/kg

- ↓ SVR ∴ ↓ MAP

- 10% increase in heart rate.

xxx copyright need to draw own graph.

[Temporal relationships between hormonal and hemodynamic changes in early human pregnancy. Chapman AB; Kidney Int 1998 Dec; 54(6):2056-63.]

- Venous return diverted through epidural veins.

Neurological:

- Emotional lability.

- Anterior pituitary increases in size threefold.

Haematological:

- Increase in red cell mass but overall haemodilution.

- Hypercoagulable state: increases in clotting factors (II, XII, X), decreased protein S, decreased responsiveness to protein C (see coagulation ).

Renal

- ↑RPF by 40%, ∴ ↑GFR.

- Urinary stasis.

Gastrointestinal

- decreased tone in lower oesophageal sphincter, pressure on stomach, reflux.

Metabolic

- VO2 increases by 20%.

- 30% fall in plasma cholinesterase (see esterases )

- Circulating triglycerides increase threefold

- cholesterol increases 50%.

- Reset osmostat down to 270mOsm/l

Locomotor

- global increase in ligament laxity.
